[[File:Des Res - geograph.org.uk - 435426.jpg|thumb|Plean Tower]]
'''Plean Tower''', also known as '''Cock-a-bendy Castle''',<ref name=cockabendy>{{cite web|url=http://www.planecastle.co.uk/castle/cock-a-bendy-castle/|title=Cock-a-bendy Castle|accessdate=2015-01-14}}</ref> '''Mengie Castle''', '''Menzies Castle''' and '''Plane Castle''', is located around {{convert|1|mi}} from [[Plean]], in [[Stirling (council area)|Stirling]], central [[Scotland]]. It comprises a small oblong [[tower house]] probably dating from the 15th century, and an adjoining 16th-century manor house.<ref name=Lindsay>Lindsay, Maurice (1986) ''The Castles of Scotland''. Constable. ISBN 0-09-473430-5 p.399</ref><ref name=Canmore>{{cite web |url=http://canmore.rcahms.gov.uk/en/site/46901/details/plean+tower/|work=Canmore|title=Plean Tower|accessdate=2013-04-15}}</ref>
==History== [[Robert Bruce]] granted the [[Scottish feudal barony|barony]] of Plean, or Plane, to John dâ€™Erth soon after 1314.<ref name=GazetteerforScotland>{{cite web |url= http://www.scottish-places.info/features/featurefirst11314.html| title=Plane Castle|work=Gazetteer for Scotland |accessdate=2013-04-15}}</ref> The castle was probably built by [[William Somerville, 2nd Lord Somerville|Lord Somerville]], who acquired the lands of Plean in 1449, through marriage.<ref name=Lindsay/>
The manor was built in about 1528.<ref name=GazetteerforScotland/> In 1643 James Somervell, 8th Lord of Plane, sold the barony and lands to meet debts.<ref name=GazetteerforScotland/> It passed to the [[Nicholson (surname)|Nicholsons]] and the [[Clan Elphinstone|Elphinstones]], but both the tower and the manor fell into disrepair. During the 1745 rebellion the [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] troops used the property.
Sir David Menzies restored the buildings in 1908, but by the 1930s they were again no longer in use.<ref name=GazetteerforScotland/> It was again restored from ruins by Nancy and John Patrick Wright and their sons in 1991-1997 <ref>http://www.celticcastles.com/castles/planecastle/history.htm</ref> to form a home and holiday accommodation.<ref name=GazetteerforScotland/>
==Structure==
Plean Castle originally had three storeys and a garret,<ref name=GazetteerforScotland/> with parapet corbelling.<ref name=Lindsay/> The great hall is in the tower; it has painted ceiling beams and a large fireplace.<ref name=GazetteerforScotland/> There is a vaulted basement in the manor house, which is connected to the tower by a wooden walkway.<ref name=GazetteerforScotland/> In the grounds there are a sculpture garden and a large pond.<ref name=GazetteerforScotland/> It is a [[listed building#Scotland|category B listed building]].<ref name="British Listed Buildings">{{cite web |url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/sc-13859-plean-tower-st-ninian-s|work=British Listed Buildings|title=Plean Castle|accessdate=2013-04-16}}</ref>
